scenes.plot_segment: Meredith Grey narrates about childhood faith in fairy tales, describing the longing for a perfect life symbolized by a white dress and Prince Charming. She reflects on how growing up leads to the loss of these fantasies, but a small part of hope remains. In the kitchen, Izzie Stevens bakes cupcakes, frustrated that she can't replicate the taste from her childhood. Meredith and Cristina Yang taste the cupcakes; Cristina jokes that Martha Stewart would be proud, but Izzie insists something is missing and refuses to call her mother for the recipe, despite encouragement from the others. Cristina suggests they sleep at Izzie's place for a change, leading to playful banter about whose house is more of a home and teasing about Meredith's morning muesli habit. Their conversation is light but hints at the closeness and complexities of their friendships. As morning arrives, Izzie offers cupcakes to the group, and Meredith’s narration continues, noting that even as people grow up and lose faith in fairy tales, most still hold onto a bit of hope that their dreams might come true.

Cristina Yang checks her rotation schedule at the hospital and tries to arrange a lighter workload so she can book a termination procedure for her pregnancy. The scheduler tells her the only available appointment is on the 16th and discusses alternatives like adoption or keeping the baby, but Cristina is uninterested in talking and confirms the procedure for the 16th, planning to rearrange her schedule if needed. Dr. Miranda Bailey leads the interns to their new patients. They meet Devo, a 17-year-old girl hospitalized for excessive bleeding after a root canal, who also has a new heart murmur and a fever. Bailey assigns Alex Karev to run labs and orders further tests. Devo jokes about her parents’ drug use and prefers to be called Esther, making light of her name and background. Meanwhile, the interns are assigned another patient, Mr. Duff, who has been transferred from psych to neuro after experiencing seizures and claiming to be psychic. The psych resident explains that Mr. Duff talks to dead people and is considered dangerous by his family. During the neurological workup, Mr. Duff predicts that someone will die on the fourth floor. The interns are skeptical but proceed with his evaluation, while his prediction becomes a topic of conversation among the hospital staff.

In the morning at the hospital, Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, Izzie Stevens, George O'Malley, and Alex Karev gather as interns discuss their new patients and the psychic patient, Mr. Duff, who predicted someone would die on the fourth floor. George is asked by Cristina to cover her shift on the 16th, but he notices she is evasive about why she needs the day off. As the group talks, Cristina and Izzie tease Meredith about her breakfast habits and debate whose house they stay at more often, with playful banter about which of their places feels more like home. The conversation shifts as Meredith presses Derek Shepherd for details about his personal life, asking about his friends and what he does outside of work. Derek is reluctant to share, insisting he is a surgeon and doesn't have friends, while Meredith pushes for more intimacy, jokingly threatening to withhold sex until he opens up. Derek suggests she should be flexible and see where things go, but Meredith insists she is not flexible, wanting real answers from him. The scene ends with tension between Meredith and Derek as she seeks honesty and connection.

Dr. Miranda Bailey explains to Devo’s Orthodox Jewish parents that their daughter, whose real name is Esther, needs a heart valve replacement due to von Willebrand’s disease, which has caused her severe bleeding. Bailey recommends a porcine (pig) valve, but Devo and her parents object for religious reasons. Izzie Stevens and Alex Karev discuss alternative options, and Izzie promises to look for a suitable substitute. Devo’s parents, visibly distressed, ultimately tell Bailey to do whatever is necessary to save their daughter’s life. Meanwhile, in another area, the interns—including Izzie, Cristina Yang, and George O’Malley—discuss Mr. Duff, the psychic patient from psych, and his unsettling prediction that someone will die on the fourth floor. Mr. Duff continues to make irreverent jokes about his supposed abilities, while the staff debate the frequency of deaths on that floor. At the same time, Dr. Derek Shepherd evaluates Mr. Walker, a patient experiencing worsening paralysis after a rock climbing fall. Despite normal imaging, Shepherd notes the progression of symptoms and orders an MRI, assigning George to accompany Mr. Walker for further evaluation.

During morning rounds, George O'Malley attempts to intubate a patient but accidentally inserts the tube into the esophagus instead of the trachea, causing the patient’s oxygen levels to drop. Dr. Miranda Bailey immediately intervenes, correcting George’s mistake and sternly reprimanding him in front of the other interns, including Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, Izzie Stevens, and Alex Karev. Bailey emphasizes the critical importance of confidence and precision in high-stakes procedures, warning George that hesitation and self-doubt can endanger patients’ lives. Embarrassed, George admits he lacks experience but insists he is usually capable. Bailey reminds him that being a surgeon requires absolute certainty and the ability to follow through under pressure, reinforcing the seriousness of their responsibilities. The other interns watch the exchange, visibly affected by the reminder of the stakes involved in their training.

Dr. Miranda Bailey reviews Mr. Duff’s MRI results with him, explaining that his episodes are epileptic seizures caused by an arteriovenous malformation (AVM) in his brain, not psychic visions. Mr. Duff is doubtful and resists further neurological testing, insisting that his experiences are real. As Bailey and the interns—specifically Izzie Stevens and Cristina Yang—try to keep him engaged, Mr. Duff suddenly appears to have another seizure-like episode. During the episode, he insists that someone on the fourth floor is going to die, unnerving the staff. Meanwhile, Izzie, who has become emotionally invested in Mr. Duff’s case, is reassigned to him after another intern requests to switch off the case, offering to take on extra work in exchange. Dr. Bailey approves the switch, assigning Izzie to both Mr. Duff and Mrs. Glass, a pregnant breast cancer patient who needs a pelvic exam.

Dr. Derek Shepherd reviews Mr. Walker’s case with the interns, noting that his MRI scans are clear and there is no obvious explanation for his worsening paralysis. Dr. Shepherd grows frustrated with the lack of answers and presses George O’Malley for more information, but George is unable to provide new insights. Derek asks if Mr. Walker has any personal or psychological stressors, but dismisses the idea that the symptoms are psychosomatic. Meanwhile, Dr. Miranda Bailey and Izzie Stevens meet with Mrs. Glass, a pregnant breast cancer patient, and her husband. The medical team explains that aggressive cancer treatment would require terminating the pregnancy, forcing Mrs. Glass to choose between her own life and the baby’s. Mrs. Glass and her husband are devastated by the impossible decision they face, struggling to process the consequences of either choice.

Mr. Walker’s paralysis continues to worsen, prompting Dr. Derek Shepherd and the interns to debate whether his symptoms are psychosomatic or caused by an undetected physical issue. Dr. Miranda Bailey leads the discussion, considering the possibility of a conversion disorder due to emotional trauma, while Dr. Shepherd remains unconvinced and pushes for further investigation. During the conversation, Mr. Duff, the patient who claims to be psychic, interrupts and insists that Mr. Walker is not “crazy,” defending him against the suggestion of a psychological cause. Dr. Shepherd orders a more advanced MRI to search for a missed clot in Mr. Walker’s upper spine. Meanwhile, in another room, Devo (Esther), the teenage heart patient, and her Orthodox Jewish parents argue with Dr. Bailey and Izzie Stevens about the use of a porcine (pig) valve for her valve replacement surgery. Devo expresses her frustration about the religious implications and debates with her parents about faith and her own beliefs. Dr. Bailey firmly explains that the procedure is necessary to save Devo’s life, but Izzie promises to look for alternative options that would respect the family’s religious concerns.

Alex Karev accompanies Mr. Duff, a patient claiming to be psychic, as he is prepped for an MRI. Mr. Duff flirts with the MRI technician, joking about her being attracted to him and making lighthearted comments. During the scan, Mr. Duff surprises the technician by mentioning chocolate cupcakes, correctly guessing what she had for breakfast, which unsettles her. She suspects he is using keen observation and reading body language rather than possessing psychic abilities. Alex observes the exchange, skeptical but intrigued by Mr. Duff’s apparent insights. Meanwhile, in the intern locker room, Cristina Yang encourages George O’Malley to ask out a nurse after a tough shift, but George is discouraged by his recent failed intubation. Izzie Stevens joins in the teasing, and the group jokes about consulting Mr. Duff, the “psychic,” for advice on their personal lives.

Mrs. Glass, a 47-year-old breast cancer patient who is unexpectedly pregnant, discusses her situation with Dr. Miranda Bailey. She explains her long struggle with infertility and the shock of becoming pregnant at her age, only to be diagnosed with cancer. Dr. Bailey compassionately but directly outlines the medical realities: aggressive cancer treatment would require terminating the pregnancy, while delaying treatment to keep the baby would significantly reduce Mrs. Glass’s chances of survival. Mrs. Glass and her husband grapple with the heartbreaking decision, weighing the risks to her life against their hope for a child. Meanwhile, in another part of the hospital, Dr. Derek Shepherd evaluates Mr. Walker, a patient experiencing worsening paralysis after a rock climbing accident. Despite normal MRI results, Derek suspects a missed clot in the upper spine and decides to operate, trusting his instincts. Intern Alex Karev questions the decision, but Derek insists on taking the risk to save Mr. Walker’s life.

Mrs. Glass and her husband meet with Dr. Miranda Bailey to discuss their options regarding her breast cancer diagnosis during pregnancy. After an emotional conversation weighing the risks to both mother and baby, they decide to continue the pregnancy, declining immediate aggressive chemotherapy. Dr. Bailey explains the implications and outlines a plan for close monitoring. Meanwhile, Dr. Derek Shepherd and Meredith Grey scrub in for surgery on Mr. Walker, whose paralysis is worsening despite inconclusive MRI results. Meredith expresses concern about proceeding without clear evidence, but Derek insists on exploring for a possible clot. The atmosphere in the OR is tense as Derek, Meredith, and the surgical team methodically search the upper spine. Meredith assists under Derek’s guidance, voicing her doubts but following his lead. After a careful and stressful exploration, Derek locates and removes a hidden clot compressing Mr. Walker’s spinal cord, restoring hope for his recovery. The team breathes a collective sigh of relief as the source of the paralysis is finally addressed.

Mrs. Glass and her husband meet with Dr. Miranda Bailey to discuss the risks of continuing her pregnancy while undergoing treatment for breast cancer. Dr. Bailey explains that aggressive cancer therapy would require terminating the pregnancy, but Mrs. Glass and her husband, after much deliberation, decide to keep the baby despite the danger to Mrs. Glass’s life. Dr. Bailey emphasizes that survival is not guaranteed and recommends a psychiatric consult to help them process the decision, but Mrs. Glass declines, expressing her determination to find happiness in the time she has and to live for her baby. Her husband supports her choice, though both acknowledge the difficult odds. Meanwhile, in the OR, Dr. Derek Shepherd and Cristina Yang continue spinal surgery on Mr. Walker, searching for a clot that could be causing his paralysis. Derek instructs Cristina to stay focused and keep looking, reminding her of the importance of persistence in high-stakes surgery.

George O'Malley is urgently called to intubate a patient whose oxygen saturation is dropping. Nervous after a previous failed attempt, George hesitates but, with encouragement from Dr. Miranda Bailey, manages to successfully intubate the patient. Bailey praises George for his composure under pressure, boosting his confidence. Meanwhile, Alex Karev, who previously suggested using a bovine valve for Devo (Esther), is allowed by Dr. Preston Burke to scrub in on Devo’s surgery after he arranges for the valve’s delivery. Burke reminds Alex that taking initiative doesn’t earn him special treatment and instructs him to find a rabbi to bless Devo before the operation, respecting her family’s religious beliefs.

During Mr. Walker’s spinal surgery, Dr. Derek Shepherd leads the team as they finally locate the elusive clot compressing the spinal cord at the second thoracic vertebra. Meredith Grey assists, and together they carefully suction and pack the area, visibly relieved to have identified the cause of Mr. Walker’s paralysis after previous negative scans. Derek acknowledges Meredith’s diagnostic instincts, telling her she was right about the clot. As the surgery concludes, Derek is urgently paged to oncology, leaving Meredith to finish closing. Outside the OR, Dr. Miranda Bailey informs Mr. Walker’s family that the source of the paralysis has been removed and the progression has stopped, but it’s uncertain whether the existing paralysis will be permanent. Meredith quietly reflects on the importance of faith—believing in what you can’t always see—and how sometimes, hope and reality can coexist.

Meredith Grey and Derek Shepherd discuss the status of their relationship in the hospital hallway. Meredith presses Derek for more information about his personal life, asking about his friends and what he does outside of work. Derek is evasive, joking that as a surgeon he doesn’t have friends, but Meredith insists she wants to know more about him before taking their relationship further, teasing that she’ll keep her pants on until he opens up. Derek encourages her to be flexible and see where things go, but Meredith wants a reason to believe in them as a couple. Meanwhile, Mrs. Glass, the pregnant breast cancer patient, is discharged from the hospital. She tells Dr. Miranda Bailey that she and her husband have made the decision to keep the baby despite the risks to her own health, stating that they don’t need Bailey’s approval but hope she can understand their choice.

Izzie Stevens brings consent forms to Mr. Duff, who is experiencing another seizure and appears anxious about his upcoming brain surgery. He confides in Izzie that he fears losing his psychic visions, which have defined his sense of self, and worries about who he will be if they disappear. Izzie reassures him, saying that if his visions are truly real, he will still have them after the AVM is removed. Meanwhile, in Devo’s hospital room, Izzie arranges for a rabbi to bless Devo before her bovine valve replacement surgery, honoring her family's Orthodox Jewish faith. The surgical team, led by Dr. Preston Burke and assisted remotely by Dr. Chesney from the Cleveland Clinic via video link, prepares for the complex procedure, ensuring the correct bovine valve is ready and that all religious considerations are respected.

In the early morning at Meredith’s house, Izzie Stevens is baking cupcakes, frustrated that she can’t replicate the taste from her childhood and refusing to call her mother for the recipe. Meredith Grey and Cristina Yang tease her, with Cristina joking that Martha Stewart would be proud and Meredith encouraging Izzie to just call her mom. The three debate whose house they stay at more often, with Cristina suggesting they sleep at Izzie’s for a change. As they get ready for the day, Cristina checks her schedule and tries to arrange a lighter rotation for an upcoming procedure, but the only available slot is on the 16th. Cristina is counseled about her pregnancy options but decides to schedule the procedure for the 16th, planning to confirm after rearranging her shifts. The conversation is lightened by playful banter about their routines and whose place feels most like home, highlighting the closeness and support among the interns as they prepare to face another day at the hospital.

Mr. Walker, recovering from spinal surgery after his rock climbing accident, lies in his hospital bed as Dr. Derek Shepherd and intern George O'Malley check on his progress. Walker reports that he’s regaining some sensation in his stomach and feet, though he still lacks bladder and bowel control. He thanks George for believing his symptoms were real and not psychosomatic. George asks him to try moving his toes, and Walker manages to wiggle them, marking a significant improvement. Derek acknowledges the progress, and George beams with relief and pride at the positive outcome.

Meredith Grey narrates about the persistence of faith and hope, even as childhood fantasies fade with age. In the hospital, Mr. Duff wakes up after his brain surgery and thanks Izzie Stevens for believing in him. He offers her a tip for her cupcake recipe—one tablespoon of coconut extract—which Izzie realizes is the missing ingredient she’s been searching for. Meredith’s narration reflects on how real life rarely matches fairy tales, but happiness can still be found in unexpected moments. Later, Meredith and Derek Shepherd walk together outside the hospital. Meredith asks Derek personal questions, wanting to know more about him beyond his role as a surgeon. Derek opens up, sharing details about his family and quirks, and tells Meredith that the rest she’ll have to take on faith. Their conversation is warm and hopeful, suggesting the possibility of a deeper connection as they walk side by side.

Meredith Grey calls her mother, Ellis Grey, using the childhood nickname "Cricket," and quietly tells her that she’s been thinking about her. Meredith’s narration reflects on faith and the hope that people can surprise you. Later, Derek Shepherd opens up to Meredith, sharing personal details about his family, favorite foods, hobbies, and quirks, revealing his vulnerability and trust. Meredith listens, realizing that sometimes you have to take things on faith, and that people can take your breath away in unexpected ways.
